nodes.text: Machine learning can provide novel insights and opportunities to solve important challenges in reliability engineering and safety, leading to more accurate analyses, better decision-making, and more effective accident prevention
Machine learning comprises major categories: supervised, unsupervised, semi-supervised, reinforcement learning, and deep learning architectures that span or implement these categories

Supervised ML regression and classification are widely applied to prognostics and health management tasks such as remaining useful life (RUL) estimation, degradation prediction, and fault classification

Evidence: Methods used for regression and classification include SVR, decision trees, random forests, Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) for UQ, and deep neural networks (DNN/CNN/RNN/LSTM) which achieve high accuracy in RUL and component reliability tasks

Unsupervised and supervised ML anomaly detection and clustering are effective for early fault and damage detection, online monitoring, and PHM across domains (e.g., turbines, bearings, spacecraft telemetry, wind turbines)

Evidence: Deep models (CNN, autoencoders, LSTM) can merge feature extraction and detection (e.g., CNN for bearing fault detection from raw signals, stacked denoising autoencoders and Extreme Learning Machine for gas turbine combustor anomaly detection, LSTM for context anomalies in spacecraft telemetry), showing high sensitivity but often with high false positive rates
Semi-supervised learning (SSL) leverages abundant unlabeled data alongside limited labels to improve prognostics and fault detection when labels are scarce or costly

Evidence: Successful SSL applications include graph-based methods achieving high detection/classification accuracy (example: solar PV fault detection with graph-based method reported 99% accuracy using less than 2% labeled data) and deep generative/ladder network approaches for RUL

Reinforcement learning, especially deep reinforcement learning (DRL), is promising for inspection and maintenance policy optimization, large-state decision problems, sampling strategies, and mobility/handover optimization; safe reinforcement learning is required when exploration risks are hazardous

Evidence: DRL has been applied to condition-based maintenance planning for multi-component systems, to deep RL-based sampling for structural reliability (outperforming standard sampling), and to mobility/load balancing in cellular networks; these works show DRL can address curse-of-dimensionality in large state/action spaces

Deep learning provides distinctive advantages for high-dimensional, nonlinear problems common in reliability and safety (feature hierarchy, end-to-end learning, superior empirical accuracy), making it especially suitable for PHM and anomaly detection

Evidence: Empirical studies report deep models (CNN, RNN, LSTM, DBN, autoencoders) often outperform shallow ML in RUL estimation, fault diagnosis and anomaly detection, but deep models are computationally expensive and harder to interpret

Uncertainty quantification, uncertainty reduction, and deployment considerations (false alarm rates, confidence intervals, scalability) are critical for ML adoption in reliability and safety decisions

Evidence: Gaussian Process Regression and extensions (Deep Gaussian Processes) provide principled uncertainty quantification; Deep Gaussian Processes and Generative Adversarial Networks are promising advanced tools for improved uncertainty estimation, surrogate modeling, and high-dimensional generative modeling in reliability and safety

Limitation: Practical challenges include high false positive rates in anomaly detection (operational adoption barrier), publication bias and unsafe SSL use when assumptions fail, computational cost and interpretability of deep models, and scalability for large streaming multivariate data

Conclusion: ML (including deep, semi-supervised, reinforcement, and probabilistic models) can materially improve PHM, RUL estimation, anomaly detection, and fleet/system-of-systems safety analytics and integration with accident databases and wearables, but realizing impact requires addressing UQ, scalability, safety-aware learning, interpretability, and deployment challenges
